subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA STOCK NEWS: RBA Rate Decision due later, Japan and South Korea are closed
content:
AUSTRALIA

AGL Energy (AGL AT) - Co. reaffirms FY profit guidance of AUD 780mln-860mln. (Newswires)

Dexus (DXS AT) - Co. Q3 occupancy by income 97.2% vs. Prev. 97.4% Q/Q, Co. is to take steps to reduce costs including layoffs and salary cuts. (Newswires)

James Hardie Industries (JHX AT) - Co. revises FY20 adj. net guidance to AUD 350mln-355mln from AUD 350mln-370mln, while it suspends its divided and will reduce global workforce by around 375 workers. (Newswires)

National Storage REIT (NSR AT) - Co. in trading halt as it announces AUD 300mln institutional placement and AUD 30mln share purchase plan. (AFR)

Prime Media (PRT AT) - Co. FY To April rev. fell 12.7% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Qantas (QAN AT) - Co. secured additional AUD 550mln in debt funding and states that current stand down of employees will be extended at least till end-June, while international flight cancellations will be extended through to end-July and notes the group is currently operating 5% of domestic passenger network and 1% of its international network. (Newswires)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Queensland government’s QIC is looking to appoint an adviser to help compile a bid for the airline. (Newswires)

Other News - Australian Treasurer Frydenberg will kickstart the drive to reopen the economy today by warning Australia's economy will lose AUD 4bln weekly if restrictions are kept and is already on course to contract by 10% in the June quarter. (AFR)

 

JAPAN (Closed)

Fujifilm (4901 JT) - Japan is planning to speed up approval for its Avigan drug in treating coronavirus which may occur this month. (Nikkei)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - WeWork sues the Co. for cancellation of the share purchase agreement. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan PM Abe confirmed state of emergency will be extended nationwide until May 31st, although would like to consider lifting the state of emergency before the deadline if experts conclude that this is possible based on analysis of regional infection rates. There were also reports that Tokyo is said to ask businesses in the prefecture to remain closed until month-end. (Newswires) 

 

SOUTH KOREA (Closed)

Other News South Korean Finance Minister Hong said there is a need to temporarily relax regulations that have become barriers to corporate investment, while he called on ministry officials to devise plans to revitalize private consumption. (Yonhap)

South Korea will reopen schools next week amid a continued decline in coronavirus infections. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US COVID cases +2.7% at 1,152,372 (Prev. +2.3% at 1,122,486); Death toll +2.6% at 67,456 (Prev. +1.8% at 65,735)

UK COVID-19 cases +2.1% at 190,584 (Prev. +2.4%); death toll +1% (+288). (Newswires)

Italy COVID-19 cases rise +0.6% to 211,938 (prev. +0.7% at 210,717), death toll rises +0.7% to 29,079 (prev. +0.6% at 29,079). (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the Administration is prepared to back additional COVID-19 stimulus only if needed and that he expects China to make good on trade agreement, while he added there will be significant consequences if they do not. (Newswires)

New York Governor Cuomo said regions can assess whether to reopen from May 15th and that he will base the reopening of regions on new infections, health care capacity, diagnostic capacity and contact tracing capacity. (Newswires)

German state premiers to agree on further measures to ease lockdown restrictions with Chancellor Merkel on Wednesday including reopening of shops likely from May 11th, school resumptions with rotating classes and to allow Bundesliga matches from May 15th under strict conditions without fans in stadiums. (Newswires)

Scientists in the Netherlands reportedly discovered an antibody that stops the coronavirus from infecting human cells in ground-breaking research using cultured human cells which could provide the initial step towards development of a fully human antibody to treat the virus. There were also separate reports that Israeli Defense Minister Bennett visited the Israel Institute for Biological Research in Ness Ziona on Monday where he was presented with a significant breakthrough in finding an antibody to the coronavirus which attacks the virus uniquely and can neutralize it in the body of an infected person. (Sky News/Israel National News)

 

ASIA-PAC

White House Adviser Navarro said China's handling of the pandemic is a larger issue than the trade deal. (Newswires)

An internal Chinese report from early March warned that Beijing is facing a Tiananmen-like global backlash over COVID-19 which could tip US relations into armed confrontation, according to sources. (Newswires)

Japan PM Abe confirmed state of emergency will be extended nationwide until May 31st, but added that they wish to consider lifting the state of emergency before the deadline if experts conclude that this is possible based on analysis of regional infection rates. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK tax authority HMRC said 6.3mln workers have been furloughed from 800k employers and that GBP 8bln has been claimed as of May 3rd. (Newswires)

  • EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Apr) 33.4 vs. Exp. 33.6 (Prev. 33.6). (Newswires)
  • German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 34.5 vs. Exp. 34.4 (Prev. 34.4)

 

COMMODITIES

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin expects oil markets to rebound and said the Trump Administration is looking for more storage capacity. (Newswires)

Texas RRC Commissioner Sitton said oil quotas are dead and that he will drop his proposal to mandate oil production reduction by 1mln BPD. (Newswires) 

 

US

Moody's downgraded the outlook for US local governments to negative from stable and noted the sector will face challenges for the remainder of the year and continuing into 2021. Furthermore, Moody's said the US economy is to contract by 5.7% in 2020 with a full return to pre-COVID levels in Q3 of 2021. (Newswires)

  • US Factory Orders (Mar) M/M -10.3% vs. Exp. -9.7% (Rev. -0.1%). (Newswires)
  • US Durable Goods, R MM (Mar) -14.7% (Prev. -14.4%)

 

MARKET RECAP

The week started off amid risk off conditions, with US/China tensions coming back to the fore, and tensions on the Korean peninsula. US stock futures, however, pared back losses through the course of US trade, led by dip buying in energy and tech names. Additionally, some of the baskets that were thwarted last week – momentum and growth stand out – also outperformed. Airlines (UAL, DAL, LUV, AAL) all hit after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed it had sold its entire stake in the four largest US airliners, noting how the industry has changed in a major way and it could be years before passenger levels return to pre-COVID levels. Apple (AAPL) announced a new 13-inch MacBook Pro Model at USD 1299, it also filed to issue a potential four-part offering. Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) is reportedly indefinitely postponing the USD 2bln sale of its oil & gas assets in the North Sea; Occidental’s (OXY) USD 8.8bln sales of Anadarko’s African assets to Total (FP FP) is also reportedly facing obstacles in some countries, according to WSJ citing sources. Tesla (TSLA) is reportedly extending the leave of its US employees. Elsewhere, it has reportedly applied for a UK electricity provider license, according to The Telegraph. Meanwhile, since CEO Musk’s tweet storm on Friday, the Co has not provided any more colour around Musk’s outbursts, which will likely see tensions rise between him and the SEC again. The French government has refused Amazon (AMZN) France's request for temporary unemployment schemes at six French sites. SPX +0.4% at 2843, NDX +1.3% at 8834, DJIA +0.1% at 23,750.

The TPLEX lacked direction to start the week, similar to how it ended last week. On the one hand, a risk off tone overnight had seen the curve bull-flatten, although later in the session the long-end reversed course. Another slew of corporate issuance post-earnings likely influenced the move, including USD 8.5bln from Apple (AAPL), as well as some other large cap names such as Amgen, Altria and Starbucks – Boeing’s (BA) YTD record raise of USD 25bln was only recently digested too. Furthermore, the US Treasury refunding announcement is due on Wednesday where the Treasury will explain how it intends to fund its ballooning deficits as the economy comes to a halt – the prospect of a sovereign supply ramp up is likely keeping some duration bulls on the sidelines. Meanwhile, front-end yields didn’t reverse course like the belly/long-end, accompanied by what one desk notes as what appears to be a growing of cash relative to available collateral in the system, with all three of today’s T-Bill auctions stopping through the screws and seeing higher than average bid-to-cover ratios. Meanwhile, the US Treasury expects to borrow a record USD 2.999trln in net marketable debt in Q2 (April-June), USD 3.055trln more than it estimated in February. US T-note futures (M0) settle 3 ticks higher at 138-31.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 4th: Mixed market shrugs-off US/China tensions, geopolitical concerns
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: US and China tensions rise, Treasury expects to borrow record USD 3trln in Q2, AAPL launch USD 8.5bln debt, North & South Korea exchange fire
  • COMING UP: Data:  UK Construction & Services PMI, Canadian Trade Balance, US Composite & Services PMI. Event: RBA Rate Decision & German Court ruling on ECB PSPP. Speakers: ECB’s Mersch, Fed’s Evans & Bostic. Earnings: Total, BNP, Infineon, Fiat Chrysler, Walt Disney, Allergan, Regeneron. Supply: UK & Germany.

MARKET WRAP

The week started off amid risk off conditions, with US/China tensions coming back to the fore, and tensions on the Korean peninsula. US stock futures, however, pared back losses through the course of US trade, led by dip buying in energy and tech names. Additionally, some of the baskets that were thwarted last week – momentum and growth stand out – also outperformed. Nevertheless, there was a mixed feel to trading conditions; the curve is mixed, with longer-dated yields higher on the day due to a busy corporate issuance slate, while yields along the short-end and belly were flat/lower; the curve itself had a steeper bias, with 2s30s wider by over 6bps in thin conditions. The FX picture was also mixed: the dollar retained its bid above the 50dma, the EUR was red across the board, while activity currencies under a great deal of pressure for most of the session, but recovering in later trade. Commodity currencies were mixed, with oil exporters finding their currencies going positive in late morning trade as crude futures found their way into the black. Elsewhere, gold punched its way back above 1700 again, and has stayed there as we enter APAC trade. The focus overnight will be on the RBA, although we aren’t expecting it to change the narrative too much. This week, the key jobs update will be eyed on Friday (API on Wednesday and jobless claims on Thursday, ahead of NFP Friday) and while the headline figure is going to be grim, some of the underlying details may be of more interest over the coming months (metrics such as the underemployment rate, participation rate, and savings rates will be eyed over the months ahead). Elsewhere, the BOE confab on Thursday is unlikely to be a game changer either.

NORTH AMERICA

CHINA: Anti-China rhetoric from US officials continued over the weekend. US President Trump said tariffs would be the ultimate punishment on China and warned that if China doesn't buy US goods, the US will end the trade deal. Meanwhile, Secretary of State Pompeo stated that there is enormous evidence that the coronavirus outbreak originated in a laboratory in Wuhan although he didn’t provide evidence to support the claims, while he accused China of stonewalling investigations and refusing to co-operate with experts. AP reported that new US intelligence analysis claimed that China intentionally concealed severity of coronavirus pandemic to stock up on critical medical supplies needed to combat the outbreak. A Reuters sources piece reported on an internal Chinese government report, from early March, which warned that Beijing is facing a Tiananmen-like global backlash over COVID-19 which could tip US relations into armed confrontation. The report noted that China's Belt and Road projects could be at risk due to resistance and the US could increase financial and military support for regional allies which could sever security in Asia. The report also called for cooperation as the "sound and steady development of China-US relations" is both countries' interest.

ELECTION RISK RESURFACING: The Trump administration is "turbocharging" an initiative to remove global industrial supply chains from China as it weighs new tariffs to punish Beijing for its handling of the coronavirus outbreak, Reuters reported citing officials familiar with US planning. "We've been working on [reducing the reliance of our supply chains in China] over the last few years but we are now turbo-charging that initiative," a State Department official said. Another official said "There is a whole of government push on this," and agencies were probing which manufacturing should be deemed 'essential' and how to produce these goods outside of China. The article quoted another official: "This moment is a perfect storm; the pandemic has crystallized all the worries that people have had about doing business with China," and "all the money that people think they made by making deals with China before, now they’ve been eclipsed many-fold by the economic damage" from COVID. Whether this is electioneering or a genuine threat by the Trump Administration remains to be seen -- both seem like credible scenarios. However, the political uncertainty will be a factor capping the upside, strategists have said. On the weekend, Goldman Sachs said investors have begun to ask question about US/China again, and while the bank believes that this rhetoric is more designed for domestic audiences in the US in the context of the election cycle, it cannot rule out a return to some of the issues that roiled markets last year. GS said it will be closely watching for signs that US officials are considering taking specific actions, such as the introduction of investment restrictions.

EUROPE

GERMAN COURT RULING: At 09:00BST on May 5th, the German Constitutional Court (GCC) in Karlsruhe will publish its final verdict on the legality of the ECB’s Public Sector Purchase Programme (PSPP). Desks do not believe the programme will be ruled as a violation of the German constitution, but eyes will be on whether the GCC hands out conditions that could limit the PSPP’s efficiency and flexibility (via the Bundesbank’s participation), whilst the ECB’s Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) also risks being dragged in. Click here full preview.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED PMCCF/SMCCF: The NY Fed announced that its Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCCF) would be set up to purchase eligible ETFs in early May, without giving a precise date. The statement said that the Primary Market Corporate Credit Facility (PMCCF) is expected to become operational, and the SMCCF to begin purchasing eligible corporate bonds, soon thereafter. Some had expected the FOMC meeting last week to specify details on when these facilities would be established. The mere announcement of the facilities back in March has been accredited as a key driver in supporting the narrowing of credit spreads across the spectrum, particularly IG, which has reinvigorated the debt markets as participants feel increasingly comfortable in the Fed’s backstop. In contrast to the ECB, which is a dominant bidder in European corporate offerings, the Fed’s facilities are for now – as intended - a “last resort”, where record YTD volumes in the dollar market have been seen before the facilities have even got off the ground. Thus, the mere signalling from the Fed in the form of its credit facility announcements has been considered adequate to restore confidence in the US credit markets.

RBA PREVIEW: The Reserve Bank of Australia will announce its latest policy decision on Tuesday in which the central bank is expected to maintain the Cash Rate Target at the record low of 0.25% with all surveyed analysts forecasting no change in rates. However, money markets would suggest otherwise with ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures pointing to a 62% chance of a 25bps cut and just a 38% likelihood for a hold despite the RBA previously noting that the current rate was the effective lower bound. Click here for full preview.

CRUDE

WTI (M0) SETTLED USD 0.61 HIGHER AT USD 20.39/BBL, WTI (N0) SETTLED USD 0.49 HIGHER AT 22.78/BBL; BRENT (N0) SETTLED USD 0.76 HIGHER AT USD 27.20

The energy complex had traded in the red overnight and in Europe before clawing back into positive going into the US session. The chorus of medium- to longer-term price bulls grows louder while the bearish near-term outlook remains amid acute demand contraction and storage capacity limits being tested. Crude futures continue to be strongly influenced by participants’ assessments of when the oil market will return to more balanced levels, as well as avoidance of exposure to near-term market conditions as many are rolling into further contracts earlier than normal, particularly in the physically settled WTI benchmark – June futures (M0) are due to expire May 19th and open interest in the July (N0) contract has already exceeded the June. Some of Monday’s strength had been attributed to Genscape’s latest estimate of weekly Cushing stocks, traders said, which are seen to have built by 1.8mln bbls, which if seen in the official DOE data, would mean the smallest build since mid-March. A declining growth rate of inventories should slow the reaching of storage capacity limits, although is only the initial steps to rebalancing the market. Citi’s analysts note that the recent near-term strength is a concern to them since the market has only entered a transitional phase; “the surplus will shrink, but inventories will continue to rise for the next 2-3 months. And once the market swings to a deficit, inventories will remain elevated for some further period of time.”

TEXAS Railroad Commissioner Sitton today said that he would be withdrawing his proposal for a state-mandated 1mln BPD oil production cut. The regulatory body is due to vote tomorrow on whether to pro-rate production, although Sitton noted that the opportunity to do so has been missed. Further, other voting officials have expressed opposition to mandated cuts, noting that producers have already carried out voluntary reductions and drawn attention to the relative insignificance of a cut in Texas in addressing the global market imbalance.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLE 3 TICKS HIGHER AT 138-31.

The TPLEX lacked direction to start the week, similar to how it ended last week. On the one hand, a risk off tone overnight had seen the curve bull-flatten, although later in the session the long-end reversed course. Another slew of corporate issuance post-earnings likely influenced the move, including USD 8.5bln from Apple (AAPL), as well as some other large cap names such as Amgen, Altria and Starbucks – Boeing’s (BA) YTD record raise of USD 25bln was only recently digested too. Furthermore, the US Treasury refunding announcement is due on Wednesday where the Treasury will explain how it intends to fund its ballooning deficits as the economy comes to a halt – the prospect of a sovereign supply ramp up is likely keeping some duration bulls on the sidelines. Meanwhile, front-end yields didn’t reverse course like the belly/long-end, accompanied by what one desk notes as what appears to be a growing of cash relative to available collateral in the system, with all three of today’s T-Bill auctions stopping through the screws and seeing higher than average bid-to-cover ratios. Meanwhile, the US Treasury expects to borrow a record USD 2.999trln in net marketable debt in Q2 (April-June), USD 3.055trln more than it estimated in February.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.4% at 2843, NDX +1.3% at 8834, DJIA +0.1% at 23,750.

SECTORS: Energy +3.7%, IT +1.4%, Communication Svs. +1%, Utilities +0.75%, Consumer Discretionary +0.7%, Materials +0.4%, Health Care +0.1%, Consumer Staples +0.01%, Real Estate -0.01%, Financials -0.9%, Industrials -1.3%

STOCK SPECIFICS: Airlines (UAL, DAL, LUV, AAL) all hit after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed it had sold its entire stake in the four largest US airliners, noting how the industry has changed in a major way and it could be years before passenger levels return to pre-COVID levels. Apple (AAPL) announced a new 13-inch MacBook Pro Model at USD 1299, it also filed to issue a potential four-part offering. Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) is reportedly indefinitely postponing the USD 2bln sale of its oil & gas assets in the North Sea; Occidental’s (OXY) USD 8.8bln sales of Anadarko’s African assets to Total (FP FP) is also reportedly facing obstacles in some countries, according to WSJ citing sources. Tesla (TSLA) is reportedly extending the leave of its US employees. Elsewhere, it has reportedly applied for a UK electricity provider license, according to The Telegraph. Meanwhile, since CEO Musk’s tweet storm on Friday, the Co has not provided any more colour around Musk’s outbursts, which will likely see tensions rise between him and the SEC again. The French government has refused Amazon (AMZN) France's request for temporary unemployment schemes at six French sites. Elsewhere, a Senior Engineer and VP at AWS has reportedly resigned as he disagrees with the firing of whistle-blowers who questioned the company’s health and safety practices, according to FT. General Electric (GE) Aviation unit expects global traffic to be down around 80% in Q2 when compared to the start of pandemic effect in China seen in early February. The unit also announced it is to cut its global workforce by 25% this year due to the impact on travel, according to CNBC.

EARNINGS: Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/B) recorded a record net loss of 49.75bln, adding it has furloughed workers and cut employee salaries. Tyson Foods (TSN) missed on EPS and revenue, noted it expects volumes in H2 20 to decrease and it has cut FY20 CapEx view. Sempra Energy (SRE) beat on EPS, missed on revenue although FY EPS guidance was better than expected. EARNINGS UPDATE: Credit Suisse highlight 73% of the S&P500 market cap has reported Q1 figures where on aggregate earnings are beating estimates by 3% apart from Financials who were weighed on after building heavy provisions for credit losses. The desk notes earnings are beating expectations by 8.1%, while 69% of companies are exceeding their lowered guidance.

Q1 2020 EARNINGS SEASON UPDATE: Credit Suisse highlights that 73% of the S&P 500 market cap has reported Q1 figures; on aggregate, earnings are beating estimates by 3% ex-financials, which have been pressured after building heavy provisions for credit losses. CS notes earnings are beating expectations by 8.1%, while 69% of companies are exceeding their lowered guidance.  

FOREX

USD: The US dollar is higher amid risk-off sentiment at the start of the week, and the DXY's 50dma (just under 99.30) has provided a floor for the Buck's action on Monday. Seasonality is in focus, now that we are in May; over the last decade, the buck has appreciated by 1.8% on average in eight of those ten years. This seasonality may be a function of issuance in May which may again see foreign demand for dollars. Headline risk has also supported the dollar on Monday, with renewed tensions between US and China, as November electioneering begins. Elsewhere, JPM argues that QE will play less of a driver for the USD compared to the last crisis, given the front-loaded, synchronised deployment by global policymakers; this time, QE differentiation will be more nuanced, JPM argues, and nations with large QE programmes and large fiscal and current account deficits will be vulnerable (GBP, NZD, CAD) to USD strength, while the USD's performance overall will be linked more to global growth.

EUR: The EUR is lower against the dollar and yen, though is gaining against highly cyclical/risk-sensitive currencies like the NOK, SEK and GBP. At the tail-end of last week, the single currency rose to within a stones throw of its 200dma (around the 1.1030 region), but has found the air thin above the 1.10 handle. Desks suggest that last week's upside may have been a function of spec shorts being squeezed in thin market conditions. UBS says the next focus for the single currency will be Tuesday's ruling out of Germany's constitutional court on the ECB's QE programme; "a negative ruling might be an outside chance, but nonetheless hard to ignore the risk," UBS writes, "so topside could be limited in the pair."

HAVENS: Havens were generally firmer today even against a rising buck with USDJPY crossing 107.00 to the downside as tensions between US and China increase with worries surrounding trade. Geopolitics also supporting the JPY as both North Korea and South Korea exchanged gunfire. XAU also bid which crossed above 1700 once again. The CHF however was weaker against the dollar but firmer against a weaker EUR. EURCHF downside however did hold less conviction than other EUR crosses and saw lows of 1.0525.

CYCLICALS (AUD, NZD, GBP, SEK): Amid an overall mixed risk appetite, cyclical FX performed poorly today, with underperformance in NZD although it stays above 0.6000 finding support at the 0.6010 level. AUD saw tentative trade ahead of tonight’s RBA decision (preview here). AUD will be particularly eyed given its high China exposure amid renewed tensions with the US. GBP also hit today on risk sentiment although reports suggest the UK is looking to relax lockdown measures on May 26th, 3 weeks later than some had hoped on their update set to be announced on May 7th. SEK was firmer against a weak EUR, although softer against the buck; the manufacturing PMI declined to 36.7 from a revised lower 42.6 figure.

COMMODITY (RUB, CAD, MXN): Both RUB and CAD trade rather flat at pixel time after choppy price action led by fluctuating oil prices and dollar strength. RUB saw some weakness in the morning in led by softer crude prices, although with WTI just off highs the RUB regained some ground against the dollar. CAD traded firmer against a rising buck initially aided by the bounce in oil prices although the move has pared after finding support at 1.4050, a level tested on the re-open of electronic trade, a level highlighted by Scotiabank who notes that “after finding support in the mid 1.38 area, the near-term risk has tilted back towards a retest of the 1.4265 peak from last month” although progress may be slowed at 1.4110-70 area amid “significant congestion resistance” in the USD.  The MXN however performed well despite a record low manufacturing PMI which pointed towards the sharpest declines in business conditions since the data began. The Peso however was supported by a pickup in oil prices as the US session was underway.

EMFX: BRL underperformed once again amid ongoing political uncertainty as it played catch up from its Labour daybreak while President Bolsonaro ignored the Supreme Court and Appointed its new Federal Police Director as Rolando Alexandre de Souza. ZAR however performed well recovering from recent lows which newswires are labelling as a technical rebound. TRY softer against the buck despite a firmer than expected CPI, although PMI data was dismal.

analysis_details:
• The TPLEX lacked direction to start the week, similar to how it ended last week. On the one hand, a risk off tone overnight had left the curve mixed, although later in the session the long-end reversed course. Another slew of corporate issuance post-earnings likely influenced the move, including USD 8.5bln from Apple (AAPL), as well as some other large cap names such as Amgen, Altria and Starbucks – Boeing’s (BA) YTD record raise of USD 25bln was only recently digested too. Furthermore, the US Treasury refunding announcement is due on Wednesday where the Treasury will explain how it intends to fund its ballooning deficits as the economy comes to a halt – the prospect of a sovereign supply ramp up is likely keeping some duration bulls on the sidelines. Meanwhile, front-end yields didn’t reverse course like the belly/long-end, accompanied by what one desk notes as what appears to be a growing of cash relative to available collateral in the system, with all three of today’s T-Bill auctions stopping through the screws and seeing higher than average bid-to-cover ratios. By settlement, the curve had bull-steepened.
  • US Treasury expects to borrow USD 2.999trln in net marketable debt in Q2 (April-June), USD 3.055trln more than it estimated in February Increase is mainly driven by the impact of the coronavirus outbreak which includes expenditure to help those affected and the changes to tax receipts and an increase in the assumed end of June cash balance.

subject: FX WRAP: USD up on risk-off; EUR red across the board ahead of German court ruling
analysis_details:
USD: The US dollar is higher amid risk-off sentiment at the start of the week, and the DXY's 50dma (just under 99.30) has provided a floor for the Buck's action on Monday. Seasonality is in focus, now that we are in May; over the last decade, the buck has appreciated by 1.8% on average in eight of those ten years. This seasonality may be a function of issuance in May which may again see foreign demand for dollars. Headline risk has also supported the dollar on Monday, with renewed tensions between US and China, as November electioneering begins. Elsewhere, JPM argues that QE will play less of a driver for the USD compared to the last crisis, given the front-loaded, synchronised deployment by global policymakers; this time, QE differentiation will be more nuanced, JPM argues, and nations with large QE programmes and large fiscal and current account deficits will be vulnerable (GBP, NZD, CAD) to USD strength, while the USD's performance overall will be linked more to global growth.

EUR: The EUR is lower against the dollar and yen, though is gaining against highly cyclical/risk-sensitive currencies like the NOK, SEK and GBP. At the tail-end of last week, the single currency rose to within a stones throw of its 200dma (around the 1.1030 region), but has found the air thin above the 1.10 handle. Desks suggest that last week's upside may have been a function of spec shorts being squeezed in thin market conditions. UBS says the next focus for the single currency will be Tuesday's ruling out of Germany's constitutional court on the ECB's QE programme; "a negative ruling might be an outside chance, but nonetheless hard to ignore the risk," UBS writes, "so topside could be limited in the pair."

HAVENS: Havens were generally firmer today even against a rising buck with USDJPY crossing 107.00 to the downside as tensions between US and China increase with worries surrounding trade. Geopolitics also supporting the JPY as both North Korea and South Korea exchanged gunfire. XAU also bid which crossed above 1700 once again. The CHF however was weaker against the dollar but firmer against a weaker EUR. EURCHF downside however did hold less conviction than other EUR crosses and saw lows of 1.0525.

CYCLICALS (AUD, NZD, GBP, SEK): Amid an overall mixed risk appetite, cyclical FX performed poorly today, with underperformance in NZD although it stays above 0.6000 finding support at the 0.6010 level. AUD saw tentative trade ahead of tonight’s RBA decision (preview here). AUD will be particularly eyed given its high China exposure amid renewed tensions with the US. GBP also hit today on risk sentiment although reports suggest the UK is looking to relax lockdown measures on May 26th, 3 weeks later than some had hoped on their update set to be announced on May 7th. SEK was firmer against a weak EUR, although softer against the buck; the manufacturing PMI declined to 36.7 from a revised lower 42.6 figure.

COMMODITY (RUB, CAD, MXN): Both RUB and CAD trade rather flat at pixel time after choppy price action led by fluctuating oil prices and dollar strength. RUB saw some weakness in the morning in led by softer crude prices, although with WTI just off highs the RUB regained some ground against the dollar. CAD traded firmer against a rising buck initially aided by the bounce in oil prices although the move has pared after finding support at 1.4050, a level tested on the re-open of electronic trade, a level highlighted by Scotiabank who notes that “after finding support in the mid 1.38 area, the near-term risk has tilted back towards a retest of the 1.4265 peak from last month” although progress may be slowed at 1.4110-70 area amid “significant congestion resistance” in the USD.  The MXN however performed well despite a record low manufacturing PMI which pointed towards the sharpest declines in business conditions since the data began. The Peso however was supported by a pickup in oil prices as the US session was underway.

EMFX: BRL underperformed once again amid ongoing political uncertainty as it played catch up from its Labour daybreak while President Bolsonaro ignored the Supreme Court and Appointed its new Federal Police Director as Rolando Alexandre de Souza. ZAR however performed well recovering from recent lows which newswires are labelling as a technical rebound. TRY softer against the buck despite a firmer than expected CPI, although PMI data was dismal.

subject: WTI (M0) settled USD 0.61 higher at USD 20.39/bbl, WTI (N0) settled USD 0.49 higher at 22.78/bbl; Brent (N0) settled USD 0.76 higher at USD 27.20
analysis_details:
• The energy complex had traded in the red overnight and in Europe before clawing back into positive going into the US session. The chorus of medium- to longer-term price bulls grows louder while the bearish near-term outlook remains amid acute demand contraction and storage capacity limits being tested. Crude futures continue to be strongly influenced by participants’ assessments of when the oil market will return to more balanced levels, as well as avoidance of exposure to near-term market conditions as many are rolling into further contracts earlier than normal, particularly in the physically settled WTI benchmark – June futures (M0) are due to expire May 19th and open interest in the July (N0) contract has already exceeded the June. Some of Monday’s strength had been attributed to Genscape’s latest estimate of weekly Cushing stocks, traders said, which are seen to have built by 1.8mln bbls, which if seen in the official DOE data, would mean the smallest build since mid-March. A declining growth rate of inventories should slow the reaching of storage capacity limits, although is only the initial steps to rebalancing the market. Citi’s analysts note that the recent near-term strength is a concern to them since the market has only entered a transitional phase; “the surplus will shrink, but inventories will continue to rise for the next 2-3 months. And once the market swings to a deficit, inventories will remain elevated for some further period of time.”
  • TEXAS Railroad Commissioner Sitton today said that he would be withdrawing his proposal for a state-mandated 1mln BPD oil production cut. The regulatory body is due to vote tomorrow on whether to pro-rate production, although Sitton noted that the opportunity to do so has been missed. Further, other voting officials have expressed opposition to mandated cuts, noting that producers have already carried out voluntary reductions and drawn attention to the relative insignificance of a cut in Texas in addressing the global market imbalance.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: risk-off start to the new week for most (and month for many)
content:
DXY

Coronavirus concerns have shifted somewhat from the daily rate of new cases and fatalities to the potential repercussions of US-China acrimony over its origins that could result in phase one of the trade deal being revoked and a new round of tariffs. As such, risk sentiment remains averse to the benefit of the Dollar with the index recovering from its post end of April hangover and surviving several wobbles to establish a firmer base above 99.000.

CAD/NOK/RUB/MXN 

All paring losses vs the Greenback alongside similar moves in the crude complex, as the Loonie reclaims 1.4100+ status, Norwegian Krona trades firmer vs the Euro around 11.3200 compared to circa 11.4650 at one stage, Rouble rebounds just over a big figure from nearly 76.0000 and Mexican Peso tests 24.3000 having been down to 24.8770 earlier.

EUR/NZD/CHF/GBP

The Euro and Kiwi are propping up the G10 table, albeit not faring that much worse than the Pound or Swiss Franc in terms of percentage declines against the Buck. Eur/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both looking precarious above round numbers at 1.0900 and 0.6000 respectively, with the former losing the prop of a 1bn option expiry at the strike and latter not deriving lasting momentum on the COVID-19 front after NZ recorded zero new infections or via S&P reaffirming the sovereign’s AA standing with a positive ratings outlook. Meanwhile, Usd/Chf is edging beyond 0.9560 and Cable is closer to 1.2400 than 1.2400, though Eur/Chf and Eur/Gbp are both lower due to the aforementioned marginal single currency underperformance.

JPY/AUD

Also poised near psychological levels and looking vulnerable to handing back more of their recent gains to the Usd if it continues to recover, as the Yen skirts 107.00 and Aussie flirts with 0.6400. Not much reaction to confirmation of Japan extending lockdown to the end of May on the latest Golden Week holiday, though the Aud should be more sensitive to the looming RBA policy meeting given ‘expectations’ for no change in rates, but money market pricing still far from convinced about no further easing – check out our headline feed and research suite for a full preview of the event.

SEK/EM

Choppy Monday sessions, as the Swedish Crown stages a similar comeback to its Scandi neighbour despite more acute manufacturing sector contraction, albeit with the aid of more pronounced Euro depreciation post-EZ PMIs, Sentix and downbeat SPF economic updates, while the Lira has not been able to turn the tide following firmer than expected Turkish inflation data. Elsewhere, the Real was already racking up corrective or catch up loses on return from Brazil’s Labour Day break, but also had to contend with more political drama after President Bolsonaro went against the Supreme Court and appointed Rolando Alexandre de Souza as Federal Police director. However, the Rand has staged another recovery with some solace taken from SA manufacturing PMI falling less than anticipated.

ANALYSIS: What to watch in the US/NY COVID-19 stats in the days/weeks ahead
content:
• Data on the weekend showed that the case count had cooled to a pace of 2.3% D/D from 2.8% prior (the average pace was 2.6% D/D between 27th April to 3rd May); the death toll increase rate cooled to 1.8% D/D from 2.8% prior (last week's average pace was 3.3%). For NY State specifically, the case count cooled to 1.1% D/D from 1.5% (average between 27th April and 3rd May was 1.3% D/D); the pace of the death toll had fallen to 1.5% D/D from 1.6% (average was 1.8% over that same period).
  • NOTE: The CDC states that numbers reported on Saturdays and Sundays are preliminary and not yet confirmed by local health departments. Accordingly, these numbers may be revised when the numbers are updated on Monday.
  • Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security director Tom Inglesby on Sunday told NBC that the COVID incubation period meant it would take two-to-three weeks for any spike in infections due to relaxed restrictions to become apparent. US President Trump was hopeful on the weekend that there would be a vaccine by the end of the year, and said he wanted schools and Universities to be open in September.
  • New Jersey Governor Murphy said he will announce a plan for school re-openings on Monday (today). New York City Mayor De Blasio said reopening the city was "obviously a few months away at the minimum", while the Washington State Governor extended the stay at home order through May 31st.
  • Weekend press has been full of warnings (don't expect a quick recovery, WSJ reported; don't expect consumer spending to normalise quickly, Barron's echoed). It is another reminder (if you needed one) that the notion of a V-shape recovery is challenged, and strategists have suggested that this may cap equities until there is more clarity.
  • Areas where clarity is required include: how reinfections will play out when lock downs are lifted, whether furloughed staff will all return, and indeed, how these events will result in bankruptcies/defaults/debt restructurings in the months ahead.
  • In terms of the COVID treatments itself, some desks have suggested that anticipation of positive Gilead (GILD) news on remdesivir was a supporting factor for equities last week, which may have prevented some from adding shorts; now that the news has passed, that 'support' may have disappeared. 
  • More broadly, the market wants to see evidence that companies continue to see the worst of the pandemic's initial fallout behind them, and late April business trends show a bounce back - companies that have alluded to this 'linearity' have performed well after earnings (notably: MSFT, FB, GOOG). 
  • And on the consumer side, jobs data normalising quickly would be a welcome sign (with a particular focus on the participation rates, underemployment rates, and savings rates for clues about consumer behaviour changes - jobs report on Friday, but these trends will take time to develop).

subject: US EQUITY OPEN NOTE: Indices open in the red as do all sectors amid resurfacing US/China tensions
content:
SNAPSHOT: Risk assets are under pressure with US/China concerns resurfacing ahead of November elections, while tensions on the Korean peninsula are once again at the fore. Futures are red, but off lows; The Dollar, the yen and gold are higher, while cyclically focused currencies are lower. Yields are lower on the Treasury curve, with spreads slightly lower.

SECTORS: All sectors open in the red with Energy outperforming amid firmer oil prices, defensives also relatively outperforming with Health Care and Utilities marginally lower in comparison to other sectors where Industrials are underperforming with General Electric (GE) weighing on the sector after a bleak update from its Aviation unit.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Airlines (UAL, DAL, LUV, AAL) all hit after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed it had sold its entire stake in the four largest US airliners, noting how the industry has changed in a major way and it could be years before passenger levels return to pre-COVID levels. Apple (AAPL) announced a new 13-inch MacBook Pro Model at USD 1299, it also filed to issue a potential four-part offering. Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) is reportedly indefinitely postponing the USD 2bln sale of its oil & gas assets in the North Sea; Occidental’s (OXY) USD 8.8bln sales of Anadarko’s African assets to Total (FP FP) is also reportedly facing obstacles in some countries, according to WSJ citing sources. Tesla (TSLA) is reportedly extending the leave of its US employees. Elsewhere, it has reportedly applied for a UK electricity provider license, according to The Telegraph. Meanwhile, since CEO Musk’s tweet storm on Friday, the Co has not provided any more colour around Musk’s outbursts, which will likely see tensions rise between him and the SEC again. The French government has refused Amazon (AMZN) France's request for temporary unemployment schemes at six French sites. Elsewhere, a Senior Engineer and VP at AWS has reportedly resigned as he disagrees with the firing of whistleblowers who questioned the company’s health and safety practices, according to FT. General Electric (GE) Aviation unit expects global traffic to be down around 80% in Q2 when compared to the start of pandemic effect in China seen in early February. The unit also announced it is to cut its global workforce by 25% this year due to the impact on travel, according to CNBC.

EARNINGS: Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/B) recorded a record net loss of 49.75bln, adding it has furloughed workers and cut employee salaries. Tyson Foods (TSN) missed on EPS and revenue, noted it expects volumes in H2 20 to decrease and it has cut FY20 CapEx view. Sempra Energy (SRE) beat on EPS, missed on revenue although FY EPS guidance was better than expected. EARNINGS UPDATE: Credit Suisse highlight 73% of the S&P500 market cap has reported Q1 figures where on aggregate earnings are beating estimates by 3% apart from Financials who were weighed on after building heavy provisions for credit losses. The desk notes earnings are beating expectations by 8.1%, while 69% of companies are exceeding their lowered guidance.

Q1 2020 EARNINGS SEASON UPDATE: Credit Suisse highlights that 73% of the S&P 500 market cap has reported Q1 figures; on aggregate, earnings are beating estimates by 3% ex-financials, which have been pressured after building heavy provisions for credit losses. CS notes earnings are beating expectations by 8.1%, while 69% of companies are exceeding their lowered guidance.  

CREDIT VS EQUITIES: Analysts are becoming increasingly bullish on corporate credit relative to equities. The fundamental driver for renewed optimism has undoubtedly been the decree of monetary stimulus, where both the Fed and ECB have moved quickly to implement backstops to credit markets and funding channels. The combination of purchases and signalling from central banks has seen spreads narrow materially from their March blowout levels, as well as bring the new issuance market to record volumes, seeing the US IG Corporate Bond ETF (LQD) almost make a full retracement to its early-March levels. UBS’s analysts have expressed their overweight position in US HY (note the HYG ETF has only made a c. 50% retracement from the lows), noting, “Since 1987, there have been 42 months with spreads in excess of 800bps, and subsequent 12-month total returns were positive in all cases but one with a median return of 24.5%.” The bank sees US HY spreads tightening to 550bps; spreads currently reside around the 800bps figure.

WATCHING DIVIDENDS: Morgan Stanley argues that dividends are what really matters for stock prices in the end. The bank says that the S&P 500 appears to be tracking the dividend futures market more closely than EPS forecasts. Its screener shows that to date, one-third of its screen has reduced or suspended dividends. "Dividend risks appear higher at the stock than the index level," MS writes, "S&P dividend futures are currently implying a 20% drop in dividend forecasts, but we think that is too bearish." although recent cash flow stress test showed that these forecasts were only likely to materialise in very stressed scenarios where companies do not use its balance sheet to defend dividends or flex payout ratios, and MS argues that this seems unlikely based on extrapolated cuts/increases YTD. "Risks still remain at the stock level though – our quant team has shown dividend cuts to be consistent with negative alpha – and our cash flow stress tests give some indication where risks may be highest."

SELL IN MAY?: The cliched, somewhat tedious adage has returned for its annual outing. Morgan Stanley argues that a correction in markets is due, perhaps to the magnitude of 10%, but this would just be a refreshing, necessary pause, the bank argues. "Our bullish view has not changed, nor has the narrative – a severe recession acknowledged by all, the bottoming rate of change in economic data/earnings revisions, seemingly unlimited central bank support, unprecedented fiscal stimulus that we believe is likely to become structural in nature and that leads to rising inflation expectations sooner than the consensus expects." The bank has, however, tilted towards High-Beta, Cyclicals and Small Caps; "While this is a change in our strategy from the past few years to be more defensive, it is not an abandonment of High Quality and/or Growth Stocks," the bank explains, "while such a rotation is difficult to trust while the data remain so weak and the outlook unclear, history suggests it's exactly what one needs to do at this stage of the cycle."

subject: ECB APP: PSPP EUR -0.738bln (Prev. EUR +9.113bln), CSPP EUR -0.062bln (Prev. EUR +0.77bln), CBPP3 EUR -0.231bln (Prev. EUR -0.010bln), ABSPP EUR -0.267bln (Prev. EUR -0.386bln)
analysis_details:
• ECB sold a net total of EUR -1.29bln across the APP programme, compared to last week’s net purchase EUR 9.487bln. Which is a marked departure from the prior week but in-fitting with the drop off seen in the weeks leading up to this; albeit, this is the first week which has printed a net sale across the APP programme in its entirety.
  • PEPP was EUR 22.09bln vs. Prev. EUR +26.04bln, an increase of 10.17% (Prev. +0.4%). The trend for PEPP has been relatively stead around the EUR 20bln or so region for the limited run of the programme so fa; however, this week’s marked increase as well as the substantial decrease in APP could potentially indicate the ECB is beginning to favour conducting its support operations via the PEPP system. As such, it will be interesting to see how this dynamic continues to evolve especially as the newly announced PELTROs begin to hit the financial system (more below).
  • In terms of last week’s purchases focus was, until mid-day Thursday at least, on whether the ECB would take any further easing actions; notably, if there would be an increase to the size of the PEPP scheme as desks calculate this is likely to run out around September/October this year at the current purchase pace. However, Lagarde and Co. refrained from making any changes to their current purchase remit but made abundantly clear a willingness to increase the size and adjust the composition as is necessary ahead.
  • At this meeting a further long-term refinancing scheme was announced, Pandemic Emergency Longer-Term Refinancing Operations or PELTROs, which are designed to provide liquidity withing the Euro Area as a backstop following the expiry of LTROs since March’20. Severn of the PELTROs will be conducted with an interest rate of -0.25% (25bp below the refi rate, which is currently 0%) first operation to be announced on May 19th and the final on December 1st. As with other operations, the ECB remarked they are prepared to provide additionally liquidity through this if required.
  • Note, German Constitutional Court is to rule on the PSPP tomorrow (May 5th) at 09:00BST. An analysis piece to this is available on the Newsquawk headline feed. Crucially, desks do not believe it will be ruled as violating the German constitution but focus will be firmly on any conditions which limit the schemes ability to operate as is needed through the Bundesbank. Could potential have some read-across to PEPP as well.

content:

May 4th, 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • Of note for Airlines (LUV, AAL, DAL, UAL), Warren Buffett announced Berkshire Hathaway has cut its entire stakes in the airline sector, after just a few years after entering the positions, noting how the industry has changed in a major way and it could be years before passenger levels return to pre-COVID levels.
  • Of note for Automakers (GM, F, FCAU, TSLA), Nissan (NSANY) is to initiate a new strategic plan where it would pull back from Europe and elsewhere to focus on the US, China and Japan, according to sources. Elsewhere, US Auto Sales stood at 8.6mln in April (prev. 16.52mln Y/Y), the lowest rate recorded since 1980, according to AutoData.
  • Of note for Health Insurers (UNH, CVS, ANTM, HUM), some are reportedly using their improved balance sheets to help struggling providers secure loans, pay claims and even sometimes underwrite patients outstanding bills, according to WSJ. Elsewhere, WSJ reports a Supreme Court decision has paved the way for the sector to receive the money it has claimed although the timing is unclear, which could include nearly USD 2bln to one “major Blue insurer”.
  • This week’s Barron’s publication highlight how Tyson Foods (TSN) looks like a good bet, while Fox (FOXA), HP (HPQ), Johnson Controls (JCI) and NetApp (NTAP) also look like buys. It added it could be argued Boeing (BA) has been punished enough, however it is not making the same kind of money as before and probably won’t for a while, the author notes. On energy, Barron’s notes “10 Energy Company Bonds That Could Reward Investors”: Occidental Petroleum (OXY), Marathon Oil (MRO), Range Resources (RRC), Comstock (CRK), Southwestern Energy (SWN), Parsley Energy (PE) Continental Resources (CLR), EQT (EQT), Cenovus (CVE), and Western Midstream Partners (WES).

DOW JONES

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) announced a new 13-inch MacBook Pro Model starting at USD 1,299. Elsewhere, AAPL has filed to issue a potential four-part offering (dollar-denominated notes due 2023, 2025, 2030, 2050), noting “we intend to use the net proceeds for general corporate purposes, including repurchases of our common stock and payment of dividends under our program to return capital to shareholders, funding for working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions and repayment of debt.”
  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) is reportedly indefinitely postponing the USD 2bln sale of its oil & gas assets in the North Sea; Occidental’s (OXY) USD 8.8bln sales of Anadarko’s African assets to Total (FP FP) is also reportedly facing obstacles in some countries, according to WSJ citing sources.
  • Intel Corp. (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) is reportedly in advanced talks to purchase Moovit, an Israeli app developer, for USD 1bln, according to Calcalist. Moovit is in charge of a free public transit app that operates in 100 countries, CNBC notes.

NASDAQ 100

  • Comcast Corp. (CMCSA) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite) is reportedly mulling layoffs at its NBC Universal media and entertainment units, according to WSJ citing sources.
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) confirmed its remdesivir received emergency use authorisation approval from the FDA, adding it aims to manufacture at least 500k treatment courses by October, and 1mln by year-end.
  • Liberty Global (LBTYA) (Communication Services/Media) – Telefonica (TEF) announced discussions with LBTYA regarding both their UK telecommunications business are in a negotiation phase and are not able to guarantee the terms or probability of its success, adding if an agreement is met, Telefonica (TEF) will announce it.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) is reportedly extending the leave of its US employees. Elsewhere, it has reportedly applied for a UK electricity provider license, according to The Telegraph. Meanwhile, since CEO Musk’s tweet storm on Friday, which wiped a significant amount of market value from the Co’s value, the Co has not provided any more colour around Musk’s outbursts, which will likely see tensions rise between him and the SEC again.

S&P 500

  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) is reportedly willing to stop selling in five European countries, including France and Spain, according to Buzzfeed.
  • Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/B) (Financials/Diversified Financial Services) Q1 20 (USD): Net loss of 49.75bln (prev. +21.66bln Y/Y). Berkshire also cut costs by furloughing employees and cutting salaries.
  • Cummins Inc. (CMI) (Industrials/Industrial Machinery) announced it has entered into a USD 2bln revolving credit facility agreement.
  • Ford Motor (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) COO Farley purchased USD 1mln worth of shares, according to an SEC filing.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) South Korean plant units announced it plans to cut production levels this month at a factory producing its new Trailblazer SUV.
  • Lilly (Eli) & Co. (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Junshi Biosciences have entered into an agreement to develop therapeutic antibodies for a potential COVID-19 treatment.
  • Public Serv. Enterprise Inc. (PEG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 1.03 (exp. 1.01), Revenue 2.78bln (exp. 3.47bln). Affirms FY20 Adj. EPS view of 3.30-3.50 (exp. 3.35).
  • Sempra Energy (SRE) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 3.08 (exp. 2.26), Revenue 3.029bln (exp. 3.09bln). FY EPS view 7.50-8.10 (exp. 7.14).
  • Tyson Foods (TSN) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) Q2 2020 (USD): Adj EPS 0.77 (exp. 1.04); Revenue 10.9bln (exp. 10.96bln); cannot anticipate how long COVID challenges will persist. Expects volumes to decrease in H2 2020. Sees Fed cattle supplies increasing 2% Y/Y in FY 2020. Recent data indicates that chicken production for the remainder of the year FY 20 will be lower than projections. Operationally, says it has and expects to continue to face slowdowns and temporary idling of some production facilities. Cuts FY 2020 CapEx view.
  • WEC Energy Group Inc (WEC) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) Q1 2020 (USD): EPS 1.43 (exp. 1.32); revenue 2.1bln (exp. 2.44bln); confirms FY EPS view.

OTHER

  • Beyond Meat (BYND) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) rival, Impossible Foods, is reportedly in talks with investors and looking for USD 500mln in funding, according to sources.
  • Canopy Growth (CGC) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) - Constellation Brands (STZ) (Consumer Staples/Distillers & Vintners) increased its stake in the name to 38.6%, adding it sees a substantial long term opportunity in the cannabis industry.
  • Ferrari (RACE IM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) Q1 2020 (EUR): Adj EBITDA 317mln (exp. 322mln); Revenue 932mln (exp. 951mln); Net profit 166mln (exp. 170mln); Cuts FY20 net revenue guidance to 3.4-3.6bln (prev. above 4.1bln); Diluted EPS guidance cut to 2.4-3.1/shr (prev. 3.90-3.95)
  • Hertz (HTZ) (Industrials/Road&Rail) has until today to pay USD 500mln or receive a waiver, according to NY Post, which noted if it does not manage to do either of these, it will likely file for bankruptcy within a matter of days.
  • Sabre Corp. (SABR) (Information Technology/IT Services) announced it has agreed to end its merger agreement with Farelogix.
  • Spirit Aerosystems (SPR) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced it is to cut 1450 staff at its Wichita, Kansas State plant due to the reduced demand for aeroplanes.
  • Uber (UBER) / Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Road&Rail) - Uber has been ordered to face a lawsuit which alleges it is using illegal predatory pricing, among other anti-competitive practices, which has hurt competition and drove smaller rival Sidecar Technologies out of business, according to reports. In a separate report, a Judge has stated Uber will have to face negligence claims after a woman accidentally got into a fake Uber vehicle and were sexually assaulted by drivers. subject: Starbucks (SBUX) has been downgraded to BBB/outlook negative at Fitch
ANALYSIS: German Constitutional Court will rule on the ECB’S PSPP on Tuesday May 5th
content:
OVERVIEW: 

At 09:00BST on May 5th, the German Constitutional Court (GCC) in Karlsruhe will publish its final verdict on the legality of the ECB’s Public Sector Purchase Programme (PSPP). Desks do not believe the programme will be ruled as a violation of the German constitution, but eyes will be on whether the GCC hands out conditions that could limit the PSPP’s efficiency and flexibility (via the Bundesbank’s participation), whilst the ECB’s Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) also risks being dragged in.

German Eurosceptics have repeatedly asked the GCC to outlaw some of the ECB’s unconventional policy responses. In a hearing late-July 2019, the GCC voiced support to claims that the ECB overstepped its mandate whilst breaching the prohibition of monetary financing. The Court also said the ECB needs to consider the negative side effects of unconventional policy. 

THE RISKS:

The ECB does not have to follow German law. The hurdles also remain high for the German court to rule against the Central Bank and thus the European Court of Justice (ECJ) - after latter ruled the programme did not infringe EU law in 2018. A simple disagreement will not be sufficient to overrule the ECJ, whilst a head-on collision with the ECB and ECJ could unravel legal issues regarding German vs. EU law.

POTENTIAL LIMITS AND FALLOUT:

Potential limits imposed on the PSPP could include: 

  1. A cap on the total monthly volumes of purchases
  2. Distribution of purchases consistent with capital keys
  3. Issuer and issue limits
  4. Eligibility criteria based on credit ratings

An imposition of limits could mean the ECB pays less attention to PSPP and more so on the PEPP, thus opening the door for a new court case against the ECB’s Pandemic Programme – which has fewer “strings” attached and hence could prove more vulnerable in court, albeit a final decision is not expected to be made before end-2021, after the PEPP expires at the end of 2020 (assuming no extension).

Rulings against these programmes would mean: 1) The Bundesbank will be put in a position where it is legally required to follow the ECB and at the same time adhere to the German Constitutional Court ruling, 2) The ECB will not be able to ignore the ruling of the highest court in the largest member state.

Desks note that the wording of the GCC ruling will be crucial to understand the ECB room for manoeuvre.

subject: Apple (AAPL) announces a new 13-inch MacBook Pro Model starting at USD 1,299
US PRE-MARKETS: US/China risk "turbocharging"; COVID recovery will not be quick
content:
SNAPSHOT: Risk assets are under pressure with US/China concerns resurfacing ahead of November elections, while tensions on the Korean peninsula are once again at the fore. Futures are red, but off lows; The Dollar, the yen and gold are higher, while cyclically focused currencies are lower. Yields are lower on the Treasury curve, with spreads slightly lower.

ELECTION RISK RESURFACING: The Trump administration is "turbocharging" an initiative to remove global industrial supply chains from China as it weighs new tariffs to punish Beijing for its handling of the coronavirus outbreak, Reuters reported citing officials familiar with US planning. "We've been working on [reducing the reliance of our supply chains in China] over the last few years but we are now turbo-charging that initiative," a State Department official said. Another official said "There is a whole of government push on this," and agencies were probing which manufacturing should be deemed 'essential' and how to produce these goods outside of China. The article quoted another official: "This moment is a perfect storm; the pandemic has crystallized all the worries that people have had about doing business with China," said another senior US official, and "all the money that people think they made by making deals with China before, now they’ve been eclipsed many-fold by the economic damage" from COVID. Whether this is electioneering or a genuine threat by the Trump Administration remains to be seen -- both seem like credible scenarios. However, the political uncertainty will be a factor capping the upside, strategists have said. On the weekend, Goldman Sachs said investors have begun to ask question about US/China again, and while the bank believes that this rhetoric is more designed for domestic audiences in the US in the context of the election cycle, it cannot rule out a return to some of the issues that roiled markets last year. GS said it will be closely watching for signs that US officials are considering taking specific actions, such as the introduction of investment restrictions.

SHAPE OF THE RECOVERY: A WSJ article Saturday argued not to expect a quick rebound in activity as the economy re-opens, since it might be a while before consumer and business behaviour normalises. This lack of V-shape recovery limits the potential for significant near-term equity upside, some strategists have argued, given the uncertainties around how reinfections will play out when lockdowns are lifted, whether furloughed staff will all return, and indeed, how these events will result in bankruptcies in the months ahead. None of this is likely to be resolved imminently, meaning that the veil of uncertainty will linger as the election cycle gets fully underway. That election cycle is already presenting some headwinds after US President Trump stoked US/China tensions last week and. While some note stock buybacks - previously a key part of equity upside - will resume in the quarters ahead, these are still likely to be negative in Y/Y terms by the end of 2020. With that said, desks have noted that this uncertainty might not necessarily translate into sharp equity downside, given the backstop provided by monetary and fiscal authorities - support which is unlikely to be pulled any time soon. For traders, this could mean horizontal trading conditions in the near-term until progress is made on some of these themes.

NORTH KOREA: Sunday news that North and South Korea exchanged gunfire across the Demilitarized Zone has brought APAC geopolitical tensions to the fore once again. Details are thin: it appears North Korea fired first, and it is also unclear what prompted the incident. Secretary of State Pompeo said he thinks it may have been an accident, and a South Korean defence official echoed that sentiment, telling AP that the country also believes the shots were likely not a calculated decision. Recently, US President Trump has been elusive on answering questions about North Korea, following reports about the health of leader Kim. However, Trump may be compelled to begin giving more specific answers following the weekend's incident, which will keep defensive plays in the mind of traders.

WATCHING DIVIDENDS: Morgan Stanley argues that dividends are what really matters for stock prices in the end. The bank says that the S&P 500 appears to be tracking the dividend futures market more closely than EPS forecasts. Its screener shows that to date, one-third of its screen has reduced or suspended dividends. "Dividend risks appear higher at the stock than the index level," MS writes, "S&P dividend futures are currently implying a 20% drop in dividend forecasts, but we think that is too bearish." although recent cash flow stress test showed that these forecasts were only likely to materialise in very stressed scenarios where companies do not use its balance sheet to defend dividends or flex payout ratios, and MS argues that this seems unlikely based on extrapolated cuts/increases YTD. "Risks still remain at the stock level though – our quant team has shown dividend cuts to be consistent with negative alpha – and our cash flow stress tests give some indication where risks may be highest."

SELL IN MAY?: The cliched, somewhat tedious adage has returned for its annual outing. Morgan Stanley argues that a correction in markets is due, perhaps to the magnitude of 10%, but this would just be a refreshing, necessary pause, the bank argues. "Our bullish view has not changed, nor has the narrative – a severe recession acknowledged by all, the bottoming rate of change in economic data/earnings revisions, seemingly unlimited central bank support, unprecedented fiscal stimulus that we believe is likely to become structural in nature and that leads to rising inflation expectations sooner than the consensus expects." The bank has, however, tilted towards High-Beta, Cyclicals and Small Caps; "While this is a change in our strategy from the past few years to be more defensive, it is not an abandonment of High Quality and/or Growth Stocks," the bank explains, "while such a rotation is difficult to trust while the data remain so weak and the outlook unclear, history suggests it's exactly what one needs to do at this stage of the cycle."

CREDIT VS EQUITIES: Analysts are becoming increasingly bullish on corporate credit relative to equities. The fundamental driver for renewed optimism has undoubtedly been the decree of monetary stimulus, where both the Fed and ECB have moved quickly to implement backstops to credit markets and funding channels. The combination of purchases and signalling from central banks has seen spreads narrow materially from their March blowout levels, as well as bring the new issuance market to record volumes, seeing the US IG Corporate Bond ETF (LQD) almost make a full retracement to its early-March levels. UBS’s analysts have expressed their overweight position in US HY (note the HYG ETF has only made a c. 50% retracement from the lows), noting, “Since 1987, there have been 42 months with spreads in excess of 800bps, and subsequent 12-month total returns were positive in all cases but one with a median return of 24.5%.” The bank sees US HY spreads tightening to 550bps; spreads currently reside around the 800bps figure.
